question.title: What's the equivalent to Marshal.ReadIntPtr(IntPtr) (C#) in Java?

node.contents: There is no Marshal.IntPtr method... are you refering to ReadIntPtr or WriteIntPtr?

astNode.text: There is no Marshal.IntPtr method... are you refering to ReadIntPtr or WriteIntPtr?

node.contents: very sorry, I mean Marshal.ReadIntPtr(IntPtr) method

astNode.text: very sorry, I mean Marshal.ReadIntPtr(IntPtr) method

node.contents: why do you need this in Java?

astNode.text: why do you need this in Java?

node.contents: I have to translate some code from c# to java. This snippet i can translate: string a = Marshal.PtrToStringAnsi((IntPtr) ptr);. But this - doesn`t: string a = Marshal.PtrToStringAnsi(Marshal.ReadIntPtr((IntPtr) ptr));

astNode.text: I have to translate some code from c# to java. This snippet i can translate: string a = Marshal.PtrToStringAnsi((IntPtr) ptr);. But this - doesn`t: string a = Marshal.PtrToStringAnsi(Marshal.ReadIntPtr((IntPtr) ptr));

node.contents: And where exactly do you get unmanaged memory from in Java? That's like asking how to dereference a pointer in java - doesn't make any sense. Obviously you could use a nio buffer, but then that already does have the usual readXXX methods (and then I don't think there's any easy way in Java to find out about native pointer sizes (and what about if the VM is using compressed Oops?)

astNode.text: And where exactly do you get unmanaged memory from in Java? That's like asking how to dereference a pointer in java - doesn't make any sense. Obviously you could use a nio buffer, but then that already does have the usual readXXX methods (and then I don't think there's any easy way in Java to find out about native pointer sizes (and what about if the VM is using compressed Oops?)

node.contents: In the second code snippet I get IntPtr form dll library. In java i get Pointer via jna.

astNode.text: In the second code snippet I get IntPtr form dll library. In java i get Pointer via jna.

node.contents: And why not return a usable java object (ie in this case probably an int array) from JNI?

astNode.text: And why not return a usable java object (ie in this case probably an int array) from JNI?

node.contents: if we have a structure (c++): struct Test { char string1; // "test" // 4 bytes int value1; // 23 // 4 bytes char * label; // *label == "str" // 4 bytes }; If pointer to this structure is "p" (com.sun.jna.Pointer), then the equivalent to Marshal.ReadIntPtr(IntPtr) is p.getPointer(8)

astNode.text: if we have a structure (c++): struct Test { char string1; // "test" // 4 bytes int value1; // 23 // 4 bytes char * label; // *label == "str" // 4 bytes }; If pointer to this structure is "p" (com.sun.jna.Pointer), then the equivalent to Marshal.ReadIntPtr(IntPtr) is p.getPointer(8)

elements.contents: public native long getAddress(long address); public native void putAddress(long address, long value); public native long allocateMemory(long size); public native long reallocateMemory(long l, long l1); public native void setMemory(long l, long l1, byte b); public native void copyMemory(long l, long l1, long l2);

units.rawText: public native long getAddress(long address); public native void putAddress(long address, long value); public native long allocateMemory(long size); public native long reallocateMemory(long l, long l1); public native void setMemory(long l, long l1, byte b); public native void copyMemory(long l, long l1, long l2);

elements.contents: import java.lang.reflect.Field; import sun.misc.Unsafe; public class Direct { public static void main(String... args) { Unsafe unsafe = null; try { Field field = sun.misc.Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); field.setAccessible(true); unsafe = (sun.misc.Unsafe) field.get(null); } catch (Exception e) { throw new AssertionError(e); } long value = 12345; byte size = 1; long allocateMemory = unsafe.allocateMemory(size); unsafe.putAddress(allocateMemory, value); long readValue = unsafe.getAddress(allocateMemory); System.out.println("read value : " + readValue); } }

units.rawText: import java.lang.reflect.Field; import sun.misc.Unsafe; public class Direct { public static void main(String... args) { Unsafe unsafe = null; try { Field field = sun.misc.Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); field.setAccessible(true); unsafe = (sun.misc.Unsafe) field.get(null); } catch (Exception e) { throw new AssertionError(e); } long value = 12345; byte size = 1; long allocateMemory = unsafe.allocateMemory(size); unsafe.putAddress(allocateMemory, value); long readValue = unsafe.getAddress(allocateMemory); System.out.println("read value : "+ readValue); } }
